page.title: 28Forestry
page.content:
Wildlife conservation is important, with a team of dedicated rangers surveying the area and improving habitats by erecting bird and bat boxes, creating wetland areas, and controlling deer numbers.

The main trade is now recreation and the tourist industry. Public access to all parts of the woodland is encouraged. As well as a mountain bike trail on the west side of the forest and more general cycle routes, there are many way-marked routes for walking, with maps for all obtainable from the Visitor Centre Shop. Orienteering, both on foot and by bicycle is also popular.

There are a number of official car parks, with parking charges now introduced on four of them. Old quarries and former timber storage areas are also used for parking.

The RAC rally no longer takes place; instead, two smaller car rallies take place, one in November and one in March. These are limited to the west side of the forest and cau se little inconvenience for residents.
Kevin Baverstock and Suzanne Tiplady
